claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 139:
When a period is provided for in hours, the period commences immediately at the specified time.



        Conclusion:
        If an agreement is made at 10:00 a.m. on June 3 of a given year that the obligation will be fulfilled within five hours,the period commences at 10:00 a.m. of the same day, which does not fall on Sunday, holiday as provided in the Act on National Holidays, or any other holiday..'''
argument: According to Article 139, when a period is provided for in hours, the period commences immediately at the specified time. In the given agreement, the obligation is to be fulfilled within five hours, starting at 10:00 a.m. on June 3. Based on Article 139, this period commences immediately at 10:00 a.m. on June 3, provided it is not a Sunday, holiday as defined by the Act on National Holidays, or any other holiday. Therefore, the premises logically entail the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 102:
An act that a person with qualified legal capacity performs as an agent of another person may not be rescinded on the grounds of qualified legal capacity; provided, however, that this does not apply to an act performed by a person with qualified legal capacity as a legal representative of another person with qualified legal capacity.
(Authority of an Agent with No Specifically Defined Authority)



        Conclusion:
        A contract may not be rescinded by the principal after it is performed by an agent with a counterparty even if it turns out that the agent was a person with limited capacity..'''
argument: According to Article 102, an act performed by a person with qualified legal capacity as an agent of another person cannot be rescinded on the grounds of qualified legal capacity. Since the agent in this case has qualified legal capacity, and the exception in Article 102 does not apply (as it specifically refers to a legal representative of another person with qualified legal capacity, not an agent in general), the contract performed by the agent with a counterparty cannot be rescinded by the principal even if it later turns out that the agent had limited capacity. This supports the conclusion that a contract may not be rescinded by the principal after it is performed by an agent with a counterparty, even if the agent was a person with limited capacity.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 9:
A juridical act performed by an adult ward is voidable; provided, however, that this does not apply to the purchase of daily necessities or to any other act involved in day-to-day life.
(Rescission of Decisions for Commencement of Guardianship)



        Conclusion:
        The purchase of daily household items may not be rescinded, even if an adult ward performed the act..'''
argument: According to Article 9, a juridical act performed by an adult ward is voidable, but this does not apply to the purchase of daily necessities or any other act involved in day-to-day life. Since the purchase of daily household items is considered a daily necessity or an act involved in day-to-day life, it falls under the exception and is therefore not voidable. Consequently, the purchase of daily household items by an adult ward may not be rescinded, which supports the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 243:
If two or more movable properties with different owners can no longer be separated without damage due to accession, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property. The same applies if excessive expense is required to separate the movables.



        Conclusion:
        If two or more movables with different owners are so joined to each other that they can no longer be separated without damaging the same, ownership of the composite Thing shall vest in the owner of the principal movables..'''
argument: The premises in Article 243 clearly state that if two or more movable properties with different owners can no longer be separated without damage due to accession, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property. The conclusion directly mirrors this premise by asserting that if two or more movables with different owners are so joined to each other that they can no longer be separated without damaging the same, ownership of the composite thing shall vest in the owner of the principal movables. Since the conclusion is a direct restatement of the premise, the premises logically entail the conclusion, supporting the claim's validity.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 192:
A person that commences the possession of movables peacefully and openly by a transactional act acquires the rights that are exercised with respect to the movables immediately if the person possesses it in good faith and without negligence.
(Recovery of Stolen or Lost Property)



        Conclusion:
        A took the jewelry that B had forgotten, believing without negligence that it belonged to A. In this case, A may not obtain the ownership of the jewelry by good faith acquisition..'''
argument: According to Article 192, a person acquires rights to movables immediately if they possess the movables in good faith and without negligence, and the possession is peaceful and open by a transactional act. In the given scenario, A took the jewelry that B had forgotten, believing without negligence that it belonged to A. However, the scenario does not specify whether A's possession of the jewelry was by a transactional act. Since the condition of a transactional act is not met, A may not obtain the ownership of the jewelry by good faith acquisition, which supports the conclusion that the argument is valid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 356:
The pledgee of immovables may use and profit from the immovables that are the subject matter of a pledge in line with the way the relevant immovables are used.
(Management Expenses Borne by Pledgees of Immovables)



        Conclusion:
        In pledges of immovables, pledgees and a pledgors may conclude a special provision that the pledgees may not use and receive the profits from the immovable property that is the subject matter of the pledge..'''
argument: The premise (Article 356) states that the pledgee of immovables may use and profit from the immovables that are the subject matter of a pledge in line with the way the relevant immovables are used. However, this premise does not explicitly state that this right is absolute and cannot be modified by agreement. Therefore, it is logically consistent to conclude that pledgees and pledgors may agree to a special provision that the pledgees may not use and receive the profits from the immovable property that is the subject matter of the pledge, as stated in the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 423-6:
If the obligee files an action concerning the exercise of the subrogor's right, the obligee must give a notice of suit to the obligor without delay.
(Obligee's Right of Subrogation to Preserve the Right to Request Registration)



        Conclusion:
        If the obligee files an action concerning the exercise of the subrogor's right, the obligee must give a notice of suit to the obligor without delay..'''
argument: The argument is valid because the premise and the conclusion are identical. According to Article 423-6, if the obligee files an action concerning the exercise of the subrogor's right, the obligee must give a notice of suit to the obligor without delay. This is exactly what the conclusion states, thus the premises logically entail the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 3-2:
If the person making a juridical act did not have mental capacity when manifesting the relevant intention, the juridical act is void.
Section 3 Capacity to Act
(Age of Majority)



        Conclusion:
        If a party to a contract did not have mental capacity when manifesting the relevant intention, the nullity of the contract may be asserted even against a third party in good faith and acting without negligence..'''
argument: According to Article 3-2, if a person making a juridical act did not have mental capacity when manifesting the relevant intention, the juridical act is void. Since a contract is a type of juridical act, if a party to a contract lacked mental capacity, the contract is void. A void contract is not legally binding, and its nullity can be asserted. Therefore, the nullity of the contract can be asserted even against a third party in good faith and acting without negligence, as stated in the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 378:
If a third party that purchases the ownership or superficies of a mortgaged immovables pays the price of the same to a mortgagee at the request of the same mortgagee, that mortgage is terminated for the benefit of that third party.
(Claims for Extinguishment of Mortgages)



        Conclusion:
        A created a mortgage on Land X, owned by A, for the benefit of B and thereafter sold Land X to C. In this case, if C pays the price of the same to B at the request of B, the mortgage shall be terminated..'''
argument: According to Article 378, if a third party (C) that purchases the ownership of a mortgaged immovables (Land X) pays the price of the same to a mortgagee (B) at the request of the same mortgagee (B), the mortgage is terminated for the benefit of that third party (C). In this case, C is a third party who has purchased the ownership of Land X, which is mortgaged to B. C pays the price of Land X to B at the request of B, as stated in Fact 3. Since all conditions of Article 378 are met, the mortgage on Land X is terminated for the benefit of C. Therefore, the argument is valid.
